intro: Sida nelsonii, commonly known as Nelson's mallows, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its woolly, silver-green foliage and showy, pale pink to purple flowers that bloom in summer. Sida nelsonii typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in desert or semi-arid environments. It is a perennial shrub that can reach heights of up to 3 feet, with simple, alternate leaves and capsule fruits that contain numerous seeds.
